text:
Yes, I knew the turing test was about telling a man and a woman apart. Listening to the beginning of the podcast (hey! I say "his or her", not just Turing, am I from the 1940s as a result?), it sounds like maybe you guys forgot something that everyone knew 10 years ago: that it's harder to make a machine with "intuition" than one that thinks "logically". Star Trek's Data was just one of many examples of people's expectations that human intuition and subtlety would be the last thing that machine intelligence would conquer. I think that's why Turing tried to design a test that would test that last thing - passing as human with all a human's subtlety - and thus certify itself as a full general intelligence. I assume the gender test was meant as proxy for subtlety, a way of encouraging the tester to look at fine details.

It turned out that the AI field solved the "intuition" and "passing as human" problems before the "general intelligence" problem, but you need to remember that people didn't expect that in advance. (Maybe it was still a bad test, I don't know, I haven't thought it through)

text: What I didn't like about Turing was Turing machines: they're an awkward concept theoretically (lambda calculus is way more elegant) and the way they work is drastically different from real computers in practice, despite the superficial resemblance.
